questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasional blood in the stool. A stool sample is collected for examination, and cysts of Entamoeba histolytica are identified under the microscope. Which form of Entamoeba histolytica is responsible for infection in humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • histolytica passes its life cycle in a single species of host (man).
  • The quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica. This mature cyst, which contains four nuclei, is the stage that is passed in the feces of an infected person and is capable of surviving in the environment.
  • When a human ingests these mature cysts (typically through contaminated food or water), they pass through the stomach unharmed. In the small intestine, they excyst (break open) to release the active, invasive trophozoites, which then colonize the large intestine and cause disease. Therefore, the form responsible for initiating the infection is the quadrinucleate cyst.

Explanation of other options:

  • Trophozoite (Option A): The trophozoite is the pathogenic, tissue-invasive form responsible for the actual symptoms (diarrhea, dysentery, tissue damage). However, it is not the infective form. Trophozoites are fragile and are destroyed by gastric acid if ingested; they cannot survive outside the host to transmit the infection.
  • Uninucleate cyst and Binucleate cyst (Option B and C): These are immature cyst stages. As a cyst matures in the intestine, it undergoes nuclear division, progressing from one nucleus to two, and finally to four. A uninucleate or binucleate cyst is not yet mature. If passed in stool, it may not be immediately infective, as it needs to mature further in the environment to become a quadrinucleate cyst. The definitive, environmentally stable, and transmissible infective form is the quadrinucleate cyst.

choices.text: Formation of a refractile cyst wall

questions.text: Which of the following events does not occur during the conversion of an uninucleate cyst to a mature quadrinucleate cyst in Entamoeba histolytica?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The chromatoid bodies are structures made of RNA typically present in the uninucleate cyst, break down as part of the maturation process.
  • In the life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica, the transition from a uninucleate cyst to a mature quadrinucleate cyst involves several key changes:
    • As the cyst matures, a refractile cyst wall is formed, which is a protective feature that makes the cyst resistant to environmental conditions, helping the organism survive outside the host.(Option A ruled out)
  • During cyst maturation, the large glycogen mass within the uninucleate cyst gradually reduces in size as the cyst progresses toward the quadrinucleate stage.(Option B ruled out)
  • Progressive nuclear division is a vital stage in the maturation process during which the single nucleus of the uninucleate cyst undergoes multiple divisions, ultimately resulting in a mature quadrinucleate cyst containing four nuclei.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Match the virulence factors of E. histolytica with their mode of action -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amoebapores are pore-forming proteins that are inserted into the membrane of host cells (such as immune cells and intestinal epithelial cells). This creates channels in the membrane, disrupting its integrity and causing the cell to lyse and die. This is a key mechanism for the parasite to evade host defenses and kill cells. (Option A and C ruled out)
  • Entamoeba histolytica moves via pseudopodia ("false feet"). This active, crawling motility is essential for the trophozoite to migrate through the mucus layer of the intestine and penetrate the mucosal surface to invade the underlying tissues. (Option D ruled out)
  • This lectin is a key surface protein that binds to galactose and N-acetyl-D-galactosamine (Gal/GalNAc) sugars present on the surface of host intestinal cells and in the mucus. This binding is the critical first step of infection, allowing the amoeba to adhere tightly to the intestinal lining before it begins to invade and cause damage.
  • These are enzymes secreted by the amoeba that break down proteins. They degrade the extracellular matrix of the host's tissues, disrupt cell junctions, and cleave components of the immune system. This widespread proteolytic (protein-digesting) activity is responsible for the characteristic liquefactive necrosis and tissue destruction seen in amoebic colitis and liver abscesses.

choices.text: Many discrete ulcers with pinhead center
Healing of ulcer without scar formation

questions.text: Which is the most consistent finding about intestinal amoebic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most consistent finding in an intestinal amoebic ulcer is the presence of many discrete ulcers with a pinhead center.
  • This presentation is characteristic of infection with Entamoeba histolytica, which typically affects the large intestine, most frequently the cecum and ascending colon. (Option A ruled out)
  • Although amoebic ulcers can be deep and are classically described as flask-shaped on microscopic examination, a single, flask-shaped ulcer is not the most consistent gross finding, the multiplicity of the lesions is a far more reliable feature.(Option B ruled out)
  • Furthermore, because these ulcers are deep and cause significant tissue destruction in the submucosa, they heal with scar formation and do not resolve without leaving fibrotic tissue.(option D ruled out)

choices.text: Presence of trophozoite with ingested RBC

questions.text: A stool sample from a patient with dysentery is sent for microscopic examination. Which of the following findings best helps in distinguishing amoebic dysentery from bacillary dysentery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amoebic dysentery is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The only confirmatory and most specific diagnostic feature on stool microscopy is the presence of trophozoites with ingested RBCs.
  • This finding is considered pathognomonic(diagnostic hallmark) of E. histolytica infection and clearly distinguishes amoebic dysentery from other causes of bloody diarrhea, such as bacillary dysentery.
  • Macrophages in stool suggest an inflammatory response typical of bacterial infections but not specific for amoebiasis.This finding is characteristic of bacillary dysentery (caused by Shigella). In Shigella infection, the mucosa is infiltrated by inflammatory cells, and macrophages are commonly found in the stool, often containing phagocytosed bacteria and debris(Option A ruled out)
  • Though characteristically present in clumps, RBCs can be present discrete and it is very difficult to identify type of dysentery based on arrangement of RBCs as it is not very specific.(Option C ruled out)
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals are present in amoebic dysentery but it is also present in other parasitic infection and allergic conditions.These crystals are formed from eosinophil breakdown and are non specific, they are seen in a variety of conditions, including parasitic infections (like giardiasis or invasive amoebiasis), allergic conditions, and other inflammatory states of the gut. (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Ingested RBCs are seen in trophozoites
Cause flask shaped ulcer in large intestine
Ingestion of trophozoites do not cause infection

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, and blood in his stool after a recent trip to a rural area in Asia. A stool examination shows motile trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica, which of the following statements is not true about this infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Metastatic lesions are features of E.histolytica infection.
  • Amoeba invades the intestine and it penetrates various tissue forming metastatic lesions like liver abscess and abscess in various other organs like kidney, brain, and spleen.Trophozoites can invade through the intestinal mucosa into the portal venous system and travel to the liver, and more rarely to other organs like the brain or lungs
  • Trophozoites which have ingested RBCs is a feature by which pathogenic amoeba can be differentiated from commensal amoeba like Entamoeba coli, Entamoeba hartmanni and Endolimax nana which do not have RBCs in their cytoplasm. (Option A ruled out)
  • The classic pathological lesion of intestinal amoebiasis is a "flask-shaped" ulcer. It is narrow at the mucosal surface but broadens out as it extends deep into the submucosa, resembling a flask. This occurs most commonly in the cecum and ascending colon. (Option B ruled out)
  • The infective form of Entamoeba histolytica is the cyst. Trophozoites are the active, invasive form but are fragile and are destroyed by gastric acid if ingested. The hardy, quadrinucleate cyst survives the stomach acid and excysts in the small intestine to release trophozoites, which then colonize the large intestine. Therefore, ingesting trophozoites does not establish an infection. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of contact lens use presents with severe headache, fever, confusion, and altered mental status. A CT scan reveals brain lesions, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows an elevated white blood cell count with neutrophilic predominance. Further testing reveals the presence of amoebic trophozoites. What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the patient symptoms are suggestive of encephalitis, history indicates chronicity and csf finding of amoebic trophozoites points to granulomatous amoebic encephalitis, which is caused by Acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba

  • Acanthamoeba is the most common etiological agent of granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE).
  • GAE is a rare but fatal infection that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals(such as those with AIDS or after organ transplants), though it can also affect healthy individuals.
  • The infection is caused by Acanthamoeba, which can enter the central nervous system, leading to inflammation, granuloma formation, and brain lesions.
  • Acanthamoeba can also cause keratitisin contact lens wearers, which may lead to a disseminated infection.

Explanation of other options:

Entamoeba histolytica (Option A): It is the causative agent of amoebic dysentery and intestinal amoebiasis, leading to symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and flask-shaped ulcers in the large intestine.

Naegleria (Option C): Naegleria fowleri causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), a rapidly fatal infection that typically follows exposure to contaminated warm freshwater (e.g., lakes, hot springs). The infection occurs when cystic forms of Naegleria are introduced into the nasal passages, usually during activities like swimming. It causes acute meningoencephalitis rather than the chronic granulomatous encephalitis seen with Acanthamoeba. The disease progresses quickly, and the patient typically presents with a sudden onset of headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, stiff neck, and rapidly worsening neurological status.

Dientamoeba fragilis (Option D): Dientamoeba fragilis is an intestinal parasite that causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. It is not associated with granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE). D. fragilis infects the colon and does not typically involve the brain.

questions.text: Naegleria fowleri infection is usually transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba which thrives in warm water at low oxygen tension and is commonly found in warm fresh water of lakes, rivers and springs.
  • The primary mode of transmission for the deadly infection it causes, Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM), is inhalation of water containing the amoeba.
  • When people swim or dive in contaminated water, water is forced into the nose. The amoeba then travels from the nasal passages, through the cribriform plate, and into the brain via the olfactory nerve. Therefore, swimming is the activity most strongly associated with the transmission of Naegleria fowleri.

Explanation of other options:

Ingestion(Option A): Drinking water contaminated with Naegleria fowleri does not cause infection. The amoeba is destroyed by stomach acid. Acanthamoeba (another free-living amoeba) infection can be acquired by ingestion of cyst.

Walking barefoot in contaminated soil(Option C): Though this amoeba is present in soil like acanthamoeba, it usually does not enter through skin penetration. As only trophozoite forms are infective forms and not cysts, and trophozoites do not survive long in soil. The larva of hookworm and S.stercoralis can survive for long in soil and can enter the body through skin penetration.

By laboratory accidents (Option D): Toxoplasma, trypanosomes, Plasmodium and leishmania infection can be acquired through laboratory accidents.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from an endemic area presents with fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages containing intracellular amastigotes. Which of the following is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the parasite to humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia, along with the identification of amastigotes in macrophages from a bone marrow biopsy, is characteristic of visceral leishmaniasiscaused by Leishmania donovani.
  • The disease primarily affects internal organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. It is characterized by fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia.
  • The Leishmania parasites are transmitted to humans by the bite of infected female Phlebotomine sand flies.
  • These sand flies become infected when they feed on the blood of a host already carrying the parasite.
  • The sand fly injects the infective form of the parasite, known as promastigotes, into the human host, where they then transform into amastigotesand infect macrophages.

Explanation of other options:

Reduviid bug (option A): It is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease.

Tsetse fly (option B): It transmits Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African sleeping sickness.

Mosquitoes (option D) : they are vectors for diseases like malaria (caused by Plasmodium species) and dengue (caused by Dengue virus), but not for Leishmania.

questions.text: A 32-year-old emigrant from West Bengal, complains of fever and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. Laboratory tests revealed anemia and leukopenia. Multiple blood cultures for bacteria and fungi were negative. p24 antigen test for HIV was negative. A bone marrow biopsy was performed and a Giemsa stained smear revealed the following intracellular parasite in the picture shown. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the findings are classic for Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), caused by Leishmania donovani.

  • Epidemiology: The patient is an emigrant from West Bengal, India, which is a well-known endemic region for Visceral Leishmaniasis.
  • Clinical Presentation: The classic triad of fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly (implied by the lab findings and diagnosis) is highly characteristic.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Anemia and Leukopenia: These are hallmark features of Kala-azar, caused by bone marrow suppression and hypersplenism.
    • Negative Blood Cultures & HIV Test: This rules out typical bacterial/fungal sepsis and HIV-associated opportunistic infections, steering the diagnosis toward a parasitic cause.
  • The intracellular parasite seen on the Giemsa-stained bone marrow smear is the key, They are also called as L-D bodies and are important histological findings for diagnosis of Kala-azar. In Visceral Leishmaniasis, the amastigote form of the parasite is found inside macrophages. These appear as small, round bodies (2-4 µm) with a distinct nucleus and a rod-shaped kinetoplast.

Explanation of other options:

  • falciparum (Option B): While Plasmodium falciparum causes malaria which presents with fever and can cause anemia, it does not typically cause prominent leukopenia. Most importantly, the parasites are found inside red blood cells, not inside macrophages in the bone marrow. The blood film would show ring forms, not the amastigotes described.
  • brucei (Option C): Trypanosoma brucei causes African Sleeping Sickness. The parasites are extracellular trypomastigotes found in the blood, not intracellular forms within macrophages. The clinical presentation and geographic origin (West Bengal) also do not match.
  • cruzi (Option D): Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, endemic to the Americas. While its amastigote forms can be found intracellularly in various tissues (including cardiac muscle), the classic presentation is acute cardiac/GI disease or chronic cardiomyopathy. The clinical syndrome of fever, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia is not the hallmark of Chagas disease. The geographic history alone makes this highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. The clinician suspects visceral leishmaniasis. Which of the following specimens would be most appropriate for the diagnosis of Leishmania donovani?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Visceral leishmaniasis (VL), caused by Leishmania donovani, often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and pancytopenia. Diagnosis of VL typically requires the identification of Leishmania parasites.

Bone marrow is the most commonly used specimen for diagnosing visceral leishmaniasis. It is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of ;Leishmania parasites, as the parasites are often found in high numbers in the bone marrow, especially in patients with extensive disease.

Bone marrow aspiration is performed from the iliac crest and is the gold standard diagnostic test.

It is safer than a splenic biopsy, carrying a much lower risk of severe hemorrhage.
It allows for the demonstration of the intracellular amastigotes (Leishman-Donovan bodies) within macrophages on a Giemsa-stained smear, providing a definitive diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

  • Peripheral blood (Option B):Although Leishmania parasites can sometimes be detected in peripheral blood, they are generally not found in significant numbers. Blood smears are less sensitive for diagnosing VL, especially in the absence of active parasitemia.
  • Splenic biopsy (Option C):While splenic biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of VL, it is more invasive and carries a risk of complications such as hemorrhage. It is not typically the first choice unless other methods fail or in cases where bone marrow aspiration is not feasible.
  • Lymph node biopsy (Option D):Lymph node biopsy is not the first-line diagnostic test for VL, as the parasite is less commonly found in lymph nodes compared to bone marrow. Lymph node biopsy is more commonly used in the diagnosis of other conditions, such as tuberculosis or lymphoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man from South America presents with a persistent, disfiguring ulceration on his nose and mouth. He reports that the lesion initially appeared as a small, painless sore on his face a few months ago, but over time, it has enlarged and now involves both the nasal and oral mucosa. The patient has no significant history of travel outside his home country. Physical examination reveals a mutilating lesion involving the soft tissues of the nose, lips, and palate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation described here is characteristic of Espundia, the malignant form of muco-cutaneous leishmaniasis.

This condition is caused by infection with the protozoan parasite Leishmania braziliensis.

It primarily affects the oro-nasal mucosa, leading to disfiguring lesions, often beginning as cutaneous ulcers and later involving the mucosal tissues of the nose, mouth, and throat.

Over time, this can cause severe destruction of the facial features, including the nose and palate.

Espundia is the malignant form of muco-cutaneous leishmaniasis and is known for its ability to invade and cause destructive lesions in the nasal and oral mucosa.

The disease is endemic in parts of South and Central America, including areas like Brazil, and is typically transmitted by sandfly bites.

Explanation of other options:

Baghdad boil (Option A): This refers to cutaneous leishmaniasis, which is caused by Leishmania major or Leishmania tropica and typically presents as a localized ulcer at the site of the sandfly bite. It does not typically involve the mucosal tissues of the face, unlike Espundia.

Baghdad boil, Delhi boil and Oriental sores are the same lesions given different names in different areas caused by L.tropica.(Option B and D ruled out)

choices.text: Occurs in 2-10 % of patients of kala-azar
Skin lesion caused by Leishmania tropica
Complication of systemic infection due to L.donovani
Develops 1-2 years after recovery from systemic infection

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from an endemic region of India presents with skin lesions that developed 1.5 years after recovering from kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis). The lesions started as macules, which gradually evolved into non-ulcerating nodules on his face and limbs. He denies any new symptoms like fever or weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which statement regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition described is Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), which is a complication that develops after recovery from visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), typically caused by Leishmania donovani.

The correct statement about PKDL is that it arises 1-2 years after the systemic infection, typically manifesting as macules, papules, or nodules on the skin.

These lesions tend to not ulcerate and often affect the face, limbs, and trunk.

PKDL is caused by Leishmania donovani, not Leishmania tropica.

Leishmania tropica is responsible for cutaneous leishmaniasis (like oriental sore), where ulcerative nodules typically form at the site of the sandfly bite.

In contrast, PKDL does not involve ulceration, and the lesions are not confined to the site of the original infection but can spread across the body.

Explanation of other options:

Occurs in 2-10% of patients of kala-azar(Option A): PKDL develops in approximately 2-10% of people who have recovered from visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). It is more common in regions where kala-azar is endemic, particularly in India, Sudan, and Bangladesh.

Complication of systemic infection due to L. donovani(Option C): PKDL is a complication of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani, which can persist in the skin after the systemic infection has been treated and resolved.

Develops 1-2 years after recovery from systemic infection(Option D): PKDL typically manifests 1-2 years after the systemic infection of kala-azar has been treated. The delay in development is one of the key features that distinguishes it from primary cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is responsible for causing "Delhi boil", a localized cutaneous lesion commonly seen in parts of India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leishmania tropica is responsible for cutaneous leishmaniasis. The lesion is called Delhi boil, Baghdad boil or oriental sore.

Lesions appear as raised papules at insect bites which grow into nodules that ulcerate over a few weeks.

Lesions may be single or multiple and vary in size from 0.5-3 cm. The ulcers heal leaving behind a disfiguring scar.

Explanation of other options:

  • Leishmania donovani (Option A): This species is responsible for Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), a systemic infection affecting the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, not a localized cutaneous boil.
  • Trypanosoma cruzi (Option C): This parasite causes Chagas disease, which is endemic to the Americas. Its presentation involves cardiac and gastrointestinal complications, not localized cutaneous boils.
  • Trypanosoma brucei (Option D): This parasite causes African Sleeping Sickness. It is transmitted by tsetse flies in sub-Saharan Africa and leads to neurological symptoms, not localized skin ulcers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with fever, headache, lethargy, and irritability after returning from a medical mission in rural African villages. On examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy and a cancer on the back of his neck. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated ESR, and increased gamma globulin levels. His girlfriend reports behavioral changes, including irritability.Based on the clinical presentation, geographic history, and laboratory findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario, symptomatology along with laboratory findings are suggestive of sleeping sickness caused by Trupanosoma brucei.

  • Trypanosoma brucei is the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), transmitted by the tsetse fly. It typically occurs in sub-Saharan Africa.
  • Early signs include fever, lymphadenopathy, and a painful chance at the bite site.
  • Neurological symptoms such as irritability, lethargy, and changes in behavior develop as the parasite crosses the blood-brain barrier.
  • Lab findings such as anemia, elevated ESR, and hypergammaglobulinemia support chronic infection.
  • African Sleeping sickness:
    • Stage I: Characterized by hematogenous and lymphatic dissemination of the disease.
    • Stage II: Characterized by central nervous system involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Trypanosoma cruzi(Option B): It causes Chagas disease, prevalent in Latin America. It may cause cardiomyopathy and megaesophagus/megacolon, not common in Africa.Chagoma, a subcutaneous nodule at site of bite, can occur in T.cruzi which is accompanied by unilateral edema of eyelid (Romana's sign) which is absent here.

Leishmania donovani(Option C): Anemia along with increased gamma globulin level can also occur in Kala azar, however CNS symptoms are not prominent in Kala azar.

Toxoplasma gondii(Option D): infections caused by this organism are mostly asymptomatic in healthy individuals, often affects immunocompromised individuals or causes congenital infections.

choices.text: Wet mount examination for characteristic jerky motility
Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci
Demonstration of clue cells by gram stain

questions.text: A young adult female having profuse yellowish green offensive vaginal discharge, dysuria and dyspareunia has come to the STI clinic. Upon physical examination, mucosa has an erythematous, punctate and papilliform appearance. (Strawberry mucosa). Which rapid test/technique helps to find an etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Trichomonas vaginalis infection which can be diagnosed by examining saline wet mounts of vaginal discharge.The fastest, most inexpensive, and point-of-care diagnostic test is the wet mount examination of the vaginal discharge.

As characteristic jerky and twitching motility of trophozoite is rapidly float outside the body, it should be examined immediately upon collection.

Profuse, yellowish-green, foul-smelling discharge, dysuria, dyspareunia along with Strawberry mucosa are highly characteristic.

Explanation of other options:

Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci (Option B): This is the diagnostic test for Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It typically causes cervicitis and not vaginitis with discharge and dysuria, the discharge is typically purulent (thick and yellow/white), and the classic "strawberry" appearance is not associated with it.

KOH preparation for budding cells (Option C): A Potassium Hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize the hyphae and budding yeast cells of Candidiasis (a yeast infection). Candidiasis typically causes a thick, white, "cottage-cheese" like discharge and intense pruritus (itching), not the described profuse, foul-smelling discharge or strawberry mucosa.

Demonstration of clue cells by gram stain (Option D): Clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells covered with coccobacilli) are the hallmark of Bacterial Vaginosis (BV). BV causes a thin, white/gray, homogenous discharge with a characteristic "fishy" odor. It is not an STI in the classic sense but a disruption of the vaginal flora. It does not cause the inflammatory "strawberry" appearance or the specific symptoms described.

questions.text: A young adult after a visit to an endemic area, developed dull aching epigastric pain, belching, flatulence and diarrhea after 10-14 days. Macroscopic examination of stool shows pale colored, offensive, fatty, and float in water, containing mucus but not blood. Microscopic examination revealed trophozoite of 14 μ size with slow oscillatory motion. Most likely organism will be -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fatty, pale stool, slow oscillatory motion of trophozoites, and symptoms of gastritis, diarrhea, and bloating point strongly to Giardia intestinalis as the causative organism.

  • Giardia lamblia causes steatorrhea.
  • Stool contains excess mucus and fat due to malabsorption.
  • It adheres to intestinal mucosa by its large sucking disc and causes abnormalities in villous architecture.
  • Loss of brush border epithelium leads to deficiency of enzymes causing above mentioned symptoms.
  • As it doesn't invade, blood is absent in stool.
  • Giardia has two forms
    • Trophozoite: It is convex dorsally, concave ventrally with sucking disc and 4 pairs of flagella.
    • Quadrinucleate cyst (infective dose).

Explanation of other options:

Entamoeba histolytica And Balantidium coli(Option A & B) : they cause dysentery with the presence of blood in stool. E.histolytica trophozoites are 20-30 in size having gliding motility. B.coli trophozoites are very large 60-70 in size having rapid revolving motility.

Trichura trichuris(Option C): Though clinical pictures resemble that of Trichuris trichiura, it may also contain blood in stool. However, there will be the presence of characteristic barrel shaped eggs and not trophozoites in stool.
